qas.question: What forms is Internet Exploer 10 available as?

answers.text: a desktop program and a touch-optimized app

qas.question: What limitations were put on Adobe flash to begin with?
What improvements were made to Internet Explorer?

answers.text: increased support for HTML5, CSS3, and hardware acceleration

qas.question: Where can Adobe Flash now be used?

plausible_answers.text: a desktop program and a touch-optimized app

qas.question: What forms is Internet Explorer 11 available as?

plausible_answers.text: a desktop program and a touch-optimized app

qas.question: What forms is Internet Explorer 10 unavailable as?
What limitations weren't put on Adobe flash to begin with?

plausible_answers.text: increased support for HTML5, CSS3, and hardware acceleration

qas.question: What improvements weren't made to Internet Explorer?
Where can Adobe Flash not be used?

context: Internet Explorer 10 is included as both <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>a desktop program and a touch-optimized app<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, and includes <a2_0><b7_0>increased support for HTML5, CSS3, and hardware acceleration<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The Internet Explorer app does not support plugins or ActiveX components, but includes a version of Adobe Flash Player that is optimized for touch and low power usage. Initially, Adobe Flash would only work on sites included on <a1_0><b6_0>a "Compatibility View" whitelist<b6_0/><a1_0/>; however, after feedback from users and additional compatibility tests, an update in March 2013 changed this behavior to use a smaller blacklist of sites with known compatibility issues instead, allowing Flash to be used on <a3_0><b8_0>most sites by default<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The desktop version does not contain these limitations.
